content.title: Array builder required item back/cancel/review behavior
content.body:
# Bug Report

## What happened

From [thread](https://dsva.slack.com/archives/CBU0KDSB1/p1720005305354599) with Adam Antonioli regarding array builder issues, (includes images and video in that link): 

Case 1: When on the review page of the form, after adding a new item, the user is taken to the new item page. If the user clicks back, the form seems to unintentionally go to the main summary page instead of the review summary section.

Case 2: When on the review page of the form, when only one item has been added, after removing the last item, the user is taken to the new item page. If the user begins to fill in a field, the cancel button appears at the bottom of the page. If the user clicks this, they are able to return to the review page without filling out the required field. This is in the required flow, and so should necessarily have an item filled in. Additionally, if the user attempts to submit the form, it is correctly blocked, but the error message seems irrelevant.

Case 3: When on the review page of the form, when only one item has been added, after removing the last item, the user is taken to the new item page. If the user presses back, they are taken to the first page in the Array Builder flow. Then if they press continue, they return to the new item page. If they fill in data and press continue, they are taken to the next screen in the flow, rather than returning to the review page.

## What I expected to happen

Possible solutions: (Adam Antonioli notes)
Case 1: Perhaps removing the back button, and using the cancel and continue design of the edit flow could fix this.
Cases 2: Seems like removing the cancel button from appearing would prevent this possibility.
Case 3: Not sure here. Perhaps removing the back button would prevent this, however this locks the user on this page until they have filled out the required field(s).
As far as I can tell, all these solutions would require a re-design or modification of the existing Array Builder Platform component.

## Urgency

How urgent is this request? Please select the appropriate option below and/or provide details

- [x] This bug is blocking work currently in progress
- [ ] This bug is affecting work currently in progress but we have a workaround
- [x] This bug is blocking work planned within the next few sprints
- [ ] This bug is not blocking any work
- [ ] Other

### Details

These were all tested on the Pre-Need form, using the Required Flow Array Builder pattern here. This design is currently on branch: MBMS-68435-Self-Service-Pre-Need-Integration-and-Pre-Integration-Military-History-Removing-a-service-period-sometimes-removes-the-wrong-entry

content.title: [Bug] - 21-4138 Stepper receiving incorrect focus, not programmatically connected to h1
content.body:
### **Description**

**What is happening**
On pages in 21-4138 that have the stepper component, focus on page load is going to the stepper element. When a user tabs, the next interactive element is a form field, and since we're using legends and fieldsets correctly, the legend/h1/hint text is being announced in mac voice over (as expected) at the end of the field input label name.

**What I expected**
The VFF team had done its original testing in a mock form 21-0845. It is no longer available on staging, and the sketch files are MIA. However, [in this ticket](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/issues/468), I was able to find a screenshot of the annotations for the header part of the form that matches what I was expecting (except the annotations show the `aria-describedby` being on the stepper instead of the h1, that should be flipped and is described correctly below).

There are some tweaks that need to be made to match the original intent:
- The stepper needs to be able to have an ID
- The h1 needs `aria-describedby` on it that points to the stepper ID
- Focus on page loads needs to go to the h1+hint text (which should be the legend)

**Notes:**
- I don't think this is a show-stopper for AT testing. Because the legends are built properly, users will still hear the h1 announced, it just won't be announced as the first thing. What my request does here is basically reverse the order of what's being announced (the main thing on the page first (h1), then any hint text, then the step count.) Right now the stepper is announced first.
- I understand this may need to go back to the DST to request for the props to be added to the components. 


### **Definition of Done**
- [x] Focus goes to h1/legend on page load
- [x] Stepper is programmatically connected to h1
- [x] PR made
- [x] Reviewed on staging

### **Support Documentation**

content.title: [Bug] - 21-4138 Back link should be wrapped in <nav> instead of <div>
content.body:
### **Description**

**What is happening:**

When navigating the page as a screen reader, the back link navigational element in the typical `breadcrumb` area of the page layout, is not found.

**What I expected:**

As a user navigating a page using a screen reader, I want to be able to find the "Back link" navigating by regions.

The back link should be contained with in a  `<nav>` HTML5 region instead of a `<div>`. A div is not specific enough for an important navigational part of the page for screen readers.

The `<nav>` region needs a unique label, and I suggest `aria-label="previous-page"`

**Something to consider**
Could we make this a variant within the `va-breadcrumb` component? Or are there too many technical logistics that make this not possible?


### **Definition of Done**
- [ ] `<nav>` is used instead of `<div>`
- [ ] Screen reader users can distinguish the "previous page" `<nav>` from other `<nav>`'s on the page
- [ ] PR Made
- [ ] Reviewed on staging


### **Support Documentation**

content.title: [Bug] - 21-4138 New Primary Action link arrow does not scale with the height of the button
content.body: ### **Description** One of the requirements for accessibility testing is that at 200, 300, and 400% zoom levels, web pages follow these guidelines: - No functionality has been hidden or removed from the page. (Example: a button that is visible on desktop but hidden on a mobile device will likely be hidden at high zoom.) - Nothing overlaps. (Example: text getting covered up by other elements.) - No horizontal scrolling. (Exceptions: data tables, charts, and images.) **What I observed:** When zoomed in at higher percentages, when the text in the new action link wraps, the pointy part of the arrow does not scale with the height of the button. **What I expected:** The arrow part of the button would scale with the height of the button. However - the button still works, it is still visible and clickable as it was before, text does not overlap, line height is preserved, all text is still visible; and no horizontal scrolling is introduced. So this may not be an accessibility issue, and may not even be a bug at all. This may just be something we have to live with in CSS. I'm writing up this ticket for us to research the issue. ### **Definition of Done** - [ ] Research into css possibilities - [ ] Decide course of action ### **Support Documentation**

## Description

Create Mock-form pattern example for the Ask a user for a single response

## Details

This work stems from this Slack thread. 
https://dsva.slack.com/archives/C01DBGX4P45/p1719870042727779 

## Tasks

- [ ] Create designs for component in Figma
- [ ] Review designs with PO and/or other DST designers
- [ ] Review designs with an accessibility specialist
- [ ] Review designs with DST members
- [ ] Address any comments from reviews, if necessary
- [ ] Comment on this ticket with any accessibility considerations engineers may need to know
- [ ] Comment on this ticket with content specifications (e.g. labels and error messages)
- [ ] Comment on this ticket with a link to the designs and post in DST Slack channel

## Acceptance Criteria

### Styles & Variables/Token

- [ ] All components should be connected to VADS Component Library styles & Variables
- [ ] All components should be connected to the proper style or variable/token
  - [ ] Colors: connected to the correct color token (not primitive!) - can be found in local variables library
  - [ ] Typography: connected to the correct text style - under local styles
  - [ ] Spacing: connected to the correct spacing token or primitive
  - [ ] Icons: connected to correct icon - can be found on foundation page

### Auto layout

- [ ] Components should be as reactive as possible. Most, if not all, components should be able to be resize for either mobile, tablet, or desktop sizes
- [ ] The correct spacing should be applied to auto layout

content.title: [Bug] Check if focus is lost in form upload flow after switching to forms-library
content.body:
### **Description**

In the accessibility foundation testing that I did for the form upload project, I identified that the form [stepper was an `h4`](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/issues/1374) instead of an `h2`. I also assumed (incorrectly) that once it was changed to an `h2` that form focus would be re-established and it would go to the stepper like it does in most forms today. But that didn't happen.

Check to see how current forms like 20-10207 or 21-0966 manage focus with the h2 stepper.

#### What's happening:
When a screen reader user continues to the next page only the `<title>` is being announced.

https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/assets/117098918/8a29066b-ee1b-4e3d-9388-5ea8001b7f60



#### What I expect
When a screen reader user continues to the next page, the "stepper" on the page should be announced.  You should hear the page `<title>` announced followed by `Step x of x: step name:" 


https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/assets/117098918/88683824-86f4-471e-874d-9b1f73c9005f



### **Definition of Done**
- [ ] Investigate problem
- [ ] Make PR
- [ ] Review on staging


### **Support Documentation**

content.title: Add missing application saved message
content.body:
### **Description**

When VA switched using the V3 version of the stepper/progress indicator, forms lost the "We'll save your application on every change" text that was below the stepper. We need to add this back in via the forms library but with a few changes.

1. The text should read `We'll save your application on every change. Your in-progress ID number is #####.`
    - [Text changes suggested by NOD team in this ticket in cooperation with CAIA](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/va.gov-team/issues/81090)
    - The ID is the "Request ID" not the "Application ID" [(Source)](https://dsva.slack.com/archives/C01DBGX4P45/p1713213598406939?thread_ts=1688760811.151569&cid=C01DBGX4P45)
    
2. The paragraph text should be 16px below the stepper.

3. Because of the redundancy of this alert, and the green success alert at the bottom of the form, we should show this text only on the first step page of the form.
    - Caveat: There's [another ticket out there suggesting the removal of the green alert](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/issues/1107#issuecomment-1986381807) at the bottom due to its redundancy as well. We need to be careful that we don't remove *both* suddenly. So this ticket is only applicable to the saved application message at the top of the form page.



### **Definition of Done**
- [ ] Text approved by CAIA
- [ ] Text updated in Figma Templates (work with DST)
- [ ] Code added to forms library
- [ ]  Add/update unit tests
- [ ]  Update e2e tests
- [ ] PR Made
- [ ] Reviewed/Tested on staging

content.title: Handle multiple signatures on a form
content.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

According to our audit, there are 87 forms that require multiple signatures. We cannot digitize these forms until we create a pattern to handle the routing of a form to multiple parties to collect their digital signature.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like a team to propose a solution and then test that with users. Here is how this might work:
* We collect some basic information from the form submitter to determine who needs to sign the form. This will vary from form to form and perhaps sometimes we'll know a group to route the form to rather than relying on the user to tell us. But for this initial work we'll focus on the use case where the user knows who the form needs to be signed by. 
  * Basic information for the additional signers would be something like Name, email address, and some identifying PII (Date of birth?) - Needs guidance from Security folks.
* When a form is submitted, we don't submit it to the back-end but instead hang onto the submission in save-in-progress DB or a similar place. We fire off a notification to the identified 3rd parties that need to sign.
* The notification (email) contains a uniquely generated link for the signer which brings them to va.gov, likely asks them to authenticate (unless we can get away with the LoROTA pattern here where we just ask for any PII we gathered about the signer) and shows them the data the user submitted with the statement of truth component.
* The signed "signs" by typing their name into the statement of truth.
* Once all signers have signed, likely detected by a background job checking on the status, the form is then submitted to the appropriate API and sent to the system of record for processing.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Well, one alternative is what we do now, which is to not support forms that require multiple signatures. But that blocks 87 forms from being fully digitized. Another alternative is to make the user print out the form and get it signed, then return and use the Direct Upload functionality we are working on to submit the form. That could be an MVP of supporting this path for these forms but, it's basically sneaker net, not a real solution. Another potential solution is a 3rd party service, like a DocuSign. But those require that all parties create a duplicative account with that service which we don't want to force users to do.

**Additional context**
This is a design gap ticket. Thus it is an identified issue that needs a solution. The solution needs to come from a VFS team that does some discovery, builds a prototype, tests that out with users, and then ships that solution. We'd then document this pattern in the Design System, perhaps codify parts of it in the Forms Library, which would allow other teams to use the pattern in their forms.

content.title: Carry over Priority Processing request answers from 21-4138 sub-task
content.body: This spike is to explore the engineering level of effort required to support users who leave the 21-4138 subtask in order to submit a priority processing request within the same session. Intended behavior: If a user selects qualifying circumstances for priority processing in the 4138 subtask, and they continue in the same session to the 10207, we will carry over any selection or input they provide into the 10207. For example, if a user selects "I have another housing risk not listed here." proceeds to provide a response, and then leaves the subtask to complete a priority processing request, when they arrive on the living situations page on 10207, their answer should already be selected, and we will pre-populate their response into the text area on the 'Other living situation' details page. There are three shared pages between 20-10207 and 21-4138 | Page | Image | | :--- | :--- | | 1. Select a living situation description | | | 2. "Other housing risks" description page | | | 3. Other hardships list | |

content.title: [Feature request] Allow variables to be passed through Multi-page List and Loop
content.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**   
In the new Multi-page list and loop pattern we are not able to pass pronoun variables (getItemName) into the pages of a list and loop. This pronoun is important as it helps the form filer know whose data should be in these fields, especially when the are filling out a form on behalf of someone else.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like to be able to identify the user's information in a list and loop. For example, the same set of fields may have 3 different headings depending on who is filling out the form.

- Your information
- Veteran's information
- Claimant's information

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
We could rewrite the content of forms to not be so specific. 

**Additional context**
It may also be helpful to know only one form currently needs this pattern in our view (10207). And we are focusing on MVP/Veteran only path in the future. So it may not be worth the effort at this point. But I wanted to document the feature request.

There is no strict content guidance to do this either in our forms. However, they do strongly hint at using person-first language throughout VA.gov as much as possible.

- [Put the person first](https://design.va.gov/content-style-guide/health-content#put-the-person-before-their-conditionbut-respect-identity-first-language-when-a-community-prefers-it)
- [Use pronouns](https://design.va.gov/content-style-guide/plain-language/use-pronouns) 
- [We-us-you](https://design.va.gov/content-style-guide/we-us-you) 
    - "Sometimes for clarity, you may need to identify who you’re addressing first, before or in addition to using the second-person pronoun."

content.title: Form Upload: Design exploration - support unauthenticated access
content.body:
Over the years VA has created a handful of forms to be completed by someone other than the Veteran or non-Veteran claimant. 

Examples:
- VA Form 40-0247, Presidential Memorial Certificate
- VA Form 21-0779, Request for Nursing Home Information

These forms require signatures from third-parties who are unlikely to have an ID.me, Login.gov, or other credentials. 

In order to support non-Veteran user submissions for these forms, we need a variation of the current design that doesn't prompt the user to authenticate. These users should have the opportunity to enter in the missing metadata that would typically come from profile. 

---
Definition of done
- [ ] Figma mockups showing the flow from the detail page to submission

content.title: Implement the new Statement of Truth web component
content.body:
### Description

The design system team has released the va-statement-of-truth web component:

https://design.va.gov/components/form/statement-of-truth
https://design.va.gov/storybook/?path=%2Fdocs%2Fuswds-va-statement-of-truth--default

Our current implementation not using the new web component: https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website/blob/efb684a9e9de31a527261959bbf23f5614c777e6/src/platform/forms/components/review/PreSubmitSection.jsx#L131

I attempted to quickly implement this by just dropping it in place of the va-input and va-checkbox that we are using, but had some issues. I think the issues mainly had to do with the new vaCheckboxChange and vaInputChange functions and getting data from the events that those functions fire. To get the boolean value from the checkbox function, I had to do `event.detail.detail.checked`, which seems wrong. For the input change, I couldn't even find the inputted value in the event, only the most recently entered character, which doesn't really help. 

As far as I know, this is the first web component we've used that has more than one vaChange function, so it may be related to that. It would probably be wise to reach out to the design system team to figure out what we're supposed to look for in the event objects and to verify that there isn't an actual bug.

### Definition of done

- [ ] The statement of truth web component is implemented in PreSubmitSection.jsx

content.title: Epic: Form upload from Find a Form (enable QuickSubmit-like functionality on VA.gov)
content.body:
# File Upload

### Note: This project will be tied to this [Epic](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/va.gov-team-sensitive/issues/1961) - in reference to showing status of a form back to the user on their VA profile and confirmation page. 

## **Description**

The problem we are solving for:
1. To upload a PDF a user has filled out online or by hand, they need to use QuickSubmit, which does not currently live on VA.gov and has accessbility issues
2. Create an upload from Find a Form for users to be able to upload their form, send to Benefits Intake API and eliminate the need for the user to mail in the form


## **Product Outline**

Find A Form Changes:
1. Add an option for the user to sign in and upload a filled in PDF
2. Confirm their First, last name, SSN, Zip code and form name
3. Display a Confirmation page after they upload which is part of a separate epic - see above
4. TBD:
- Form Field validation, i.e. required fields, signature signed - will dive deeper into this once we start development


## **High Level User Story**

As a user I can download the PDF, fill it out electronically and then upload it to VA.gov

## **Hypothesis or Bet**

**If** we make this change **then** we expect their form submissions to reach the final destination - i.e VBMS, quicker, therefore process their claims quicker. Also reducing the errors on forms for required fields, - see TBD above

## **Definition of done**

- [ ] An upload option on Find a Form displayed only to forms that can be submitted to Central Mail - Benefits Intake API
- [ ] Add authentication to sign in prior to uploading the form
- [ ] Test the forms are submitted to Central Mail
- [ ] Add validation on form before submitting to Central Mail

content.title: Show status of form submissions to users on My VA and confirmation page
content.body:
## **Description**

There are three problems we are trying to solve for:
1. Forms that travel through the Benefits Intake API and into Central Mail can be accepted but don't always make it to the System of Record. When the form submission fails to reach the intended destination, the user is unaware and potentially under the assumption that their form submission is being worked on.
2. User expectations are not properly set such that they would know when to follow up with the VA if they have not received any status on their submission.
3. Forms not related to a claim or appeal that are saved "in progress" show up in draft status in MyVA (Benefit applications drafts) but then are not shown to the user anywhere on VA.gov once that form is submitted. The next contact the user may get from the VA would be when the form was processed. Leaving a potentially long gap between submission and the next communication from the VA.


## **Product Outline**

There are two main parts to this work:

A. Revising the form confirmation page for forms using the Benefits Intake API to convey to the user that their form submission is pending until it reaches the system of record (i.e. not fully received)
B. Conveying the current status, which we can obtain by polling the Benefits Intake API post-submission, to the user.

My Veteran-facing Forms team is going to take on part A and assist with part B, including documenting the process for other teams to follow. We currently poll the Benefits Intake API and reflect that status in Datadog thus we can help with obtaining the status. Chante's team is going to help us get that status into MyVA and put that in front of the user. 

Reflecting status to the user also supports the work to provide QuickSubmit-like form upload capability on VA.gov. [That work is tracked in a separate epic](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/issues/1167).

## **High Level User Story**

As a user who has submitted information to the VA via an online experience, I want to be able to track my submission and to know if it has not reached a human or system to be processed so that I might take appropriate action.

## **Hypothesis or Bet**

**If** we make this change **then** we expect to make it clear to our users when a form has reached the system of record, and when it has not, for forms that utilize the Benefits Intake API thereby giving the user greater visibility into the status of their request and greater confidence in the overall system. 

## **OKR**
Objective: Communicate form submission status to those submitting forms that rely on the Benefits Intake API.
Key result department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms#1: One form using the Benefits Intake API use an updated confirmation page template that links to a canonical view of their submission status in MyVA.
Key result department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms#2: Documentation is available that instructs VFS teams how to implement this pattern and get their form status into MyVA.
Key result department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms#3: Once department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms#1 and department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms#2 are achieved, all forms using the Benefits Intake API will have a deadline set to use this pattern to convey form submission status.

## **Definition of done**

- [ ] A revised confirmation page has been tested with users and shipped to production in a form that uses the Benefits Intake API
- [ ] The status of a form submission, as provided by the Benefits Intake API polling mechanism, is shown to the submitter in a standardized location that can be linked to from the confirmation page, and any notification being sent, while the form is being processed
- [ ] Documentation details to VFS teams how they can implement this pattern of conveying submission status to users.

There will be follow-on tasks for the Design System team to document the revised Confirmation page template and update the [Help users to stay informed of their application status pattern](https://design.va.gov/patterns/help-users-to/stay-informed-of-their-application-status).

content.title: Update Yeoman generator template
content.body:
[Form Process Documentation as [reference]](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/blob/main/Product/form_process.md)

## **Description**
As an product manager I am guided by a commitment to customer centric innovation and the overall growth our our products, forms and team. 

Each time we create a form on our current templates for the intro and confirmation page there are manual tweaks and bugs that our Engineers must fix (ie; scroll issues on confirmation page, OMB not using web component, miscellaneous tweaks etc.). 

Our proposal is to update our existing Yeoman generator template (Or create a new one) so that we can have a more consistent starting point lowering our chance of bugs that make it to the end. 

Within this update we plan to address intro and confirmation page consistencies from form to form, save in progress functionalities, any desired refactors and potentially stretch goal needs of allowing a common page. This update will ensure that all future forms don’t have to be redone each time. 
   

## **Product Outline**
[Link to Product Outline](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/VA.gov-team-forms/blob/main/Product/Yeoman/Product%20Outline.md)

## **High Level User Story**
As an engineer 
I want to Update/change our Yeoman Generator template 
So that I can have more consistent starting point lowering our chance of bugs that make it to the end.

## **Hypothesis or Bet**
 
If we make this change the we expect to see a reduced number of bugs and manual tweaks to be made at the end of form development. We could create a better experience by also reaching our stretch goal 

## **OKR**
As part of the IDEA Act, we are prioritizing forms that have the low complexity to build / high frequency of use and high impact to Veterans. 

## **Definition of done**

- [ ] Addressed intro and confirmation page consistencies from form to form
- [ ] Addressed save in progress functionalities
- [ ] Updated or new Yeoman Generator template 

## Steps for completion
### Product

- [ ] Research
- [X ] Identify Stakeholders 
- [ ] User Story & Workflow
- [X ] Product Outline- github

### Design

- [ ] Wireframes
- [ ] Walk through wireframes with the devs

### Collab Cycle Kick off

### Design Intent

### QA

content.title: Quick Submit Usability Study
content.body:
Project plan for QuickSubmit usability test

Problem statement

Given that there are 255 Veteran-facing paper forms that do not yet have a modernized experience for submission how might we help Veterans and their families submit those paper forms without having to resort to completing a PDF manually with no error validation and submitting it via snail mail so they the VA can reduce the burden of submitting a form and Veterans can feel that the VA is consistently improving their experience even when the ideal solution (a fully designed user experience) isn’t available.
Who we’re designing for: Users of VA.gov
Why they need help: Submitting a paper form puts a certain amount of burden on the submitter. There is no validation of their paper form and they have to send it in via snail mail which, according to USPS takes on average 2.5 days.
What the need is: We need a solution for submitting PDF forms filled out by-hand. Ideally that solution would accept a form, potentially validate it in some way, then submit the form to the appropriate back-end system, then provide a text and/or email confirmation that the form was received.

Project objectives

The Veteran-facing Forms team will conducts two tests:

1. Heuristic evaluation of QuickSubmit. This is to determine if the tool meets the basic accessibility requirements to be able to conduct a usability test with users of assistive tech. If the tool does not meet this minimum bar then the tool is not fit for purpose and the usability test will not continue.
2. Usability test of QuickSubmit. User research with at least 10 participants, of whom at least 3 will be users of assistive tech. We will recruit users through Perigean with the goal of finding folks who actually need to submit a form that QuickSubmit accepts. We also need folks who have IAL2 level authentication already established as QuickSubmit appears to require that level. We’ll focus on the 10 examples below where we currently point users to QuickSubmit.

What we’ll produce: Research findings and recommendations in the standard VA slide deck for sharing research.
IF (and only if) we make a recommendation that the user experience of the QuickSubmit tool meets the minimum bar for VA.gov then we’ll talk to the Intake and Delivery Services team to determine the level of monitoring and observability the team has for the tool, the tech stack the tool is built on, and other concerns related to interoperating with a tool not owned by the Platform. From that discovery we’ll produce a document detailing what would need to happen to be able to point more users at QuickSubmit.
NOTE: QuickSubmit currently makes the user re-authenticate even if they are already authenticated using Login.gov or ID.me (I re-verified this on 1/19). That would have to be fixed if we decide this is a viable path.

Open questions

* To our understanding, there is no staging environment for QuickSubmit. Thus we’ll need to test in production. That requires us recruiting users who need to submit an actual form OR agreement from the Intake and Delivery Services team that they will promptly delete any files uploaded during our testing. We’re not sure Perigean can recruit with this level of specificity and we’ve not yet engaged the team to see if they can delete uploaded files quickly.

What we won’t cover

While we’ll ask some context setting questions regarding a user’s previous experience with QuickSubmit we will not be attempting to uncover what or who generates user traffic to QuickSubmit today.
We’ll also try to avoid overlapping with any research regarding QuickSubmit vs. Ask VA as a document upload path, or at least we’ll coordinate these efforts so that any overlap is intentional.

Contextual statements

QuickSubmit sits under the Intake and Delivery Services team within the Business transformation service within the Office of Business Integration (OBI). Tim Wagner and Jacob Shepherd are on the Intake and Delivery Service team. They report to Melissa Fiedler who reports to John Clark (Chief) who reports to Derek Herbert (Director). This team (well, Tim Wagner at least) believes this tool “can’t get any easier”.
QuickSubmit replaced Direct Upload as “the online tool to share documents with VA’s Evidence Intake Center”. It has 406,500 active registered users as of 10/24/2023. Groups uploading files via QuickSubmit include Disabled American Veterans, American Legion, and Veterans of Foreign Wars. Roles using QuickSubmit include Veterans, Veteran family members, business partners, and VA employees.
QuickSubmit doesn’t currently follow the VA Design System nor the content standards that we’ve set for VA.gov. However, we currently point users to QuickSubmit in 10 places on VA.gov today:

1. https://www.va.gov/disability/dependency-indemnity-compensation/
2. https://www.va.gov/pension/survivors-pension/
3. https://www.va.gov/education/about-gi-bill-benefits/how-to-use-benefits/test-fees/
4. https://www.va.gov/burials-memorials/memorial-items/presidential-memorial-certificates/
5. https://www.va.gov/burials-memorials/memorial-items/headstones-markers-medallions/
6. https://www.va.gov/education/how-to-apply/ (for uploading supporting documents)
7. https://www.va.gov/disability/upload-supporting-evidence/ (Upload evidence for a decision review or an appeal through AccessVA)
8. https://www.va.gov/burials-memorials/eligibility/burial-in-private-cemetery/
9. https://www.va.gov/resources/how-to-change-your-legal-name-on-file-with-va/
10. https://www.va.gov/disability/dependency-indemnity-compensation-esp/
